study_identification.author_journal_year: Saashi A. Bedford et al., Biological Psychiatry, 2024
study_identification.title: Brain-Charting Autism and Attention-De /uniFB01 cit /uniFB01 Hyperactivity Disorder Reveals Distinct and Overlapping Neurobiology

clarity_of_research_objectives.reason: The abstract and introduction clearly state the research objectives, including the application of normative modeling to characterize cortical anatomy associated with autism and ADHD, examine sex and age differences, and explore co-occurrence. The PICO elements are identifiable.
clarity_of_research_objectives.supporting_text: Here, we used population modeling and a large, multisite neuroimaging dataset ( N = 4255 after quality control) to characterize cortical anatomy associated with autism and ADHD, benchmarked against models of average brain development based on a sample of more than 75,000 individuals. We also examined sex and age differences and relationship with autistic traits and explored the co-occurrence of autism and ADHD.

clear_definition_of_target_population.reason: The "Sample and Datasets" section clearly defines the target populations (autism, ADHD, typically developing controls) and specifies demographic characteristics like age and sex.
clear_definition_of_target_population.supporting_text: The /uniFB01 nal dataset after quality control (QC) included 4255 individuals (1869 typically developing control participants [687 female, 1182 male], 987 individuals with ADHD [270 female, 717 male], and 1399 autistic individuals [288 female, 1111 male], ages 2 -64 years [mean 14.0, median 12.4]) (Figure 1). ... Individuals with magnetic resonance imaging data and a primary diagnosis of autism or ADHD or no diagnosis were included.

clarity_of_inclusion_and_exclusion_crite.reason: The paper mentions inclusion criteria (MRI data, primary diagnosis of autism/ADHD or no diagnosis) and quality control procedures (FSQC tool, Euler number as covariate) which act as exclusion criteria. However, a detailed, pre-specified list of inclusion/exclusion criteria and a flow chart are not explicitly provided in the main text. The number of subjects at each stage is mentioned after QC.
clarity_of_inclusion_and_exclusion_crite.supporting_text: The /uniFB01 nal dataset after quality control (QC) included 4255 individuals... Individuals with magnetic resonance imaging data and a primary diagnosis of autism or ADHD or no diagnosis were included. ... All scans underwent manual QC of raw image and FreeSurfer surface reconstructions using our FSQC tool (107), which allows for the evaluation of both surface reconstruction and raw scan quality, including motion artifacts (108). A cutoff of 2.5 was used for FSQC (107). Because even small variations in quality can bias downstream analyses (108,109), we also included the FreeSurfer-derived Euler number (110) as a covariate in all analyses.

validity_of_normative_modeling_outcome_m.reason: The brain measures (cortical thickness, volume, surface area) are clearly defined, and the methods for quantifying individual-level deviations (centile scores using GAMLSS) are detailed. The characteristics of the normative reference population are specified.
validity_of_normative_modeling_outcome_m.supporting_text: Regional estimates of each cortical measure were extracted based on the Desikan-Killiany atlas (106). ... Our previous work (98) generated reference models using generalized additive models of location scale and shape to map neuroanatomical developmental trajectories across the life span, using a sample of 75,241 TD individuals, for total GMV, subcortical GMV (sGMV), white matter volume (WMV), ventricular volume, total SA, mean CT, regional CT, regional cortical volume (CV), and regional SA, while accounting for effects of age, sex, and site/scanner. ... Out-of-sample centile scores for our study sample were generated based on these reference models using Brent ' s maximum likelihood estimation [Supplemental Methods Section 2 (98)]. Centile scores quantify variation in brain development and range from 0 to 1, with 0.5 representing the average of the reference sample.

handling_of_confounding_variables.reason: The paper explicitly states that age, sex, and site/scanner effects were accounted for in the normative modeling. The Euler number was also included as a covariate. ComBat harmonization was used for multi-site data.
handling_of_confounding_variables.supporting_text: Our previous work (98) generated reference models using generalized additive models of location scale and shape to map neuroanatomical developmental trajectories across the life span, using a sample of 75,241 TD individuals, for total GMV, subcortical GMV (sGMV), white matter volume (WMV), ventricular volume, total SA, mean CT, regional CT, regional cortical volume (CV), and regional SA, while accounting for effects of age, sex, and site/scanner. ... ComBat was applied to the entire dataset across all global and regional measures, with each site treated as a batch and with covariates of age, sex, and diagnosis to preserve related biological variation. ... All analyses included Euler number as a covariate, as well as age, to account for potential systematic age deviations in clinical groups.

clarity_of_data_sources.reason: The paper clearly lists the names of the 7 datasets used and mentions that T1-weighted scans were combined from 49 sites.
clarity_of_data_sources.supporting_text: T1-weighted scans were combined from 49 sites across 7 datasets, including the ABIDE (Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange) (102,103), the POND (Province of Ontario Neurodevelopmental) Network, the HBN (Healthy Brain Network) at the Child Mind Institute (104), the ADHD200 Consortium, the Multimodal Developmental Neurogenetics of Females with ASD dataset from the National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive, the UK MRC-AIMS (Medical Research Council Autism Imaging Multi-centre Study), and the University of California San Diego Biomarkers of Autism study.

description_of_image_acquisition_protoco.reason: While T1-weighted scans are mentioned, the paper does not provide details on imaging parameters (TR, TE, flip angle, resolution) or scanner specifications (manufacturer, field strength). It refers to supplementary methods for details of each dataset, but these are not directly accessible in the provided `.md` file.
description_of_image_acquisition_protoco.supporting_text: T1-weighted scans were combined from 49 sites across 7 datasets...

details_of_data_preprocessing.reason: The paper specifies the software used (FreeSurfer, version 6.0.1) and details the preprocessing steps (regional estimates based on Desikan-Killiany atlas, averaging across hemispheres). Quality control procedures (manual QC using FSQC tool, Euler number) are also described.
details_of_data_preprocessing.supporting_text: T1 images from each dataset were processed using FreeSurfer, version 6.0.1 (105). Regional estimates of each cortical measure were extracted based on the Desikan-Killiany atlas (106). For computational ef /uniFB01 ciency and because BrainChart models for separate hemispheres were not available at the time of analysis, measures were averaged across hemispheres for each parcellation. Quality Control. All scans underwent manual QC of raw image and FreeSurfer surface reconstructions using our FSQC tool (107), which allows for the evaluation of both surface reconstruction and raw scan quality, including motion artifacts (108). A cutoff of 2.5 was used for FSQC (107). Because even small variations in quality can bias downstream analyses (108,109), we also included the FreeSurfer-derived Euler number (110) as a covariate in all analyses.

clarity_of_data_partitioning_methods.reason: The paper describes the overall sample size and the normative reference sample, but it does not explicitly detail how the data was partitioned into training, validation, and test sets for the current study's analyses. It mentions "out-of-sample estimates" and "out-of-sample centile scores" but not a clear partitioning strategy for the study's own dataset.
clarity_of_data_partitioning_methods.supporting_text: Our previous work (98) generated reference models using generalized additive models of location scale and shape to map neuroanatomical developmental trajectories across the life span, using a sample of 75,241 TD individuals... Out-of-sample centile scores for our study sample were generated based on these reference models...

details_of_normative_modeling_approach.reason: The paper clearly states the statistical approach used for normative modeling: Generalized Additive Models of Location Scale and Shape (GAMLSS). It also mentions that the models were generated in previous work and used for out-of-sample estimation.
details_of_normative_modeling_approach.supporting_text: Our previous work (98) generated reference models using generalized additive models of location scale and shape to map neuroanatomical developmental trajectories across the life span, using a sample of 75,241 TD individuals...

details_of_training_algorithm.reason: The paper mentions that "out-of-sample centile scores for our study sample were generated based on these reference models using Brent ' s maximum likelihood estimation." This describes the method for applying the pre-trained models, but it does not detail the training algorithms, optimization processes, hyperparameter settings, convergence criteria, or regularization techniques used to *train* the original GAMLSS models. It refers to Supplemental Methods Section 2 for details, which is not provided.
details_of_training_algorithm.supporting_text: Out-of-sample centile scores for our study sample were generated based on these reference models using Brent ' s maximum likelihood estimation [Supplemental Methods Section 2 (98)].

model_performance_evaluation_metrics.reason: The paper specifies the use of Cohen's d effect sizes and false discovery rate (FDR) correction for multiple comparisons. It also mentions Spearman correlations for assessing similarity of sex-specific effect size maps.
model_performance_evaluation_metrics.supporting_text: Multiple comparisons were controlled for using the false discovery rate correction (116), separately for each analysis and cortical measure. Cohen ' s d effect sizes were calculated using the ' t_to_d ' function in the ' effectsize ' package in R (117). We assessed the similarity of sex-speci /uniFB01 c effect size maps by calculating Spearman correlations and using spin permutation testing to assess signi /uniFB01 cance (Supplemental Methods Section 4).

implementation_of_internal_validation.reason: The paper mentions "sensitivity analyses on non-ComBat-harmonized centiles and compared in-sample and out-of-sample centiles" and "Results using in-sample and non-ComBat harmonized data were highly similar." This suggests some form of internal validation or consistency check. However, it doesn't explicitly describe a dedicated validation set from the current study's data or specific measures to detect and prevent overfitting beyond the general approach of normative modeling.
implementation_of_internal_validation.supporting_text: We also conducted sensitivity analyses on non -ComBat-harmonized centiles and compared in-sample and out-of-sample centiles (Supplemental Methods Sections 2 and 3).

external_data_validation.reason: The study uses a large, aggregated dataset from multiple sources, and applies pre-existing normative models. However, it does not perform external validation of its *findings* on a completely independent dataset that was not part of the aggregated data used in the study. The "out-of-sample" refers to applying the normative models to the study's cohort, not validating the study's specific results on a new, external cohort.
external_data_validation.supporting_text: (No explicit mention of external validation of the study's results on a new, independent dataset.)

description_of_dataset_characteristics.reason: The paper provides detailed demographic characteristics (sample sizes, age range, sex breakdown) for the overall dataset and for each diagnostic group. Clinical characteristics are mentioned in the context of the co-occurring autism and ADHD analysis.
description_of_dataset_characteristics.supporting_text: The /uniFB01 nal dataset after quality control (QC) included 4255 individuals (1869 typically developing control participants [687 female, 1182 male], 987 individuals with ADHD [270 female, 717 male], and 1399 autistic individuals [288 female, 1111 male], ages 2 -64 years [mean 14.0, median 12.4]) (Figure 1). For details of each dataset, demographics before and after QC, and group differences, see Supplemental Methods Section 1.

performance_metrics_and_statistical_unce.reason: The paper reports Cohen's d effect sizes, p-values, and q-values (FDR-corrected p-values) for statistical significance. Confidence intervals are not explicitly reported for all metrics, but statistical significance is clearly addressed.
performance_metrics_and_statistical_unce.supporting_text: Multiple comparisons were controlled for using the false discovery rate correction (116), separately for each analysis and cortical measure. Cohen ' s d effect sizes were calculated using the ' t_to_d ' function in the ' effectsize ' package in R (117).

consideration_for_reproducibility.reason: The paper mentions the software used (FreeSurfer, R packages) and refers to previous work for the normative models. It also states that "All data were analyzed consistently in house". However, it does not explicitly mention the availability of code, scripts, or trained models for the current study's analyses. Data availability is implied through the use of open datasets (ABIDE, HBN, ADHD200), but a clear statement on data sharing for the aggregated dataset is not present in the main text.
consideration_for_reproducibility.supporting_text: T1 images from each dataset were processed using FreeSurfer, version 6.0.1 (105).

interpretation_specific_to_normative_mod.reason: The paper extensively discusses the meaning of individual-level deviation scores (centile scores), compares findings to traditional case-control studies, and discusses the clinical implications and prospects for clinical application.
interpretation_specific_to_normative_mod.supporting_text: Population modeling, often referred to as normative modeling, provides a framework for studying diverse conditions in reference to a common baseline, which allows us to better quantify individual differences and address heterogeneity and multisite datasets. Population modeling also provides a potential route toward clinical and translational applications of neuroimaging (101). Similar to the use of pediatric growth charts, by characterizing typical brain development, we can identify individually speci /uniFB01 c alterations from these trajectories that may be associated with neurodevelopmental conditions even before associated traits manifest clinically.

additional_comments.additional_comments: The paper makes extensive use of supplementary materials for detailed methods and results, which were not directly accessible in the provided `.md` file. This limits the ability to fully assess some criteria, particularly those requiring deeper methodological descriptions. The paper also uses `/uniFB01` and `/uniFB02` characters which seem to be rendering issues from the PDF conversion.
